narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basics of earth science, and quantitive reasoning applied to the topic of fossil fuels. Also of the environmental impacts of fossil fuels and how these can be mitigated.

I learned everything about fossil fuels- how the form in the Earth, their chemistry, how big oil companies find and drill, as well as their effects on the environment and what we can do to address climate change. This course is very comprehensive because Professor O. is very knowledgeable.
I learned a great deal about the impact of fossil fuels and how much renewable energy impacts the environment.
Quantifying and comparing data about fossil fuels. Fossil fuel extraction and geologic processes.
I went into the course with no background knowledge. Immediately, I found it to be very educational and engaging. I came out learning so much about the course.

I learned a lot about the world's energy systems and especially about fossil fuels. My understanding of the chemical composition of fossil fuels, their geographic distribution, how they are formed and extracted, etc. was greatly improved.
I learned fundamentals in the fossil fuel system and the various considerations that need to be made towards the use of fossil fuels including life-cycle assessment, economic incentives, and history.
Learned about energy sources
knowledge on fossil fuels and world energy
Distribution of various energy types throughout the world

A useful knowledge of both the hard earth science related to fossil fuel development and use as well as the broader geopolitical significance of fossil fuels in the world economy (the latter of which I found much more interesting).
Learned about basic energy, heat, chemical science. Unit stuff, terms for environmental regulation, lots of geology. About oil fields, geologic traps, and coal mines.
You will learn more than you expect about fossil fuels.
Learned about fossil fuels and basic Earth science. Topics included: how fossil fuel systems are created, how energy markets work, and the effects of fossil fuels on climate change.
Learn about fossil fuel, the chemistry of it, how it is extracted, how do they come about, earth systems, plate tectonics, and climate change
The science, history, and economics of Fossil fuels and renewable energy. A focus on the energy transition and its effects on climate.
Pretty interesting material
Learned a lot about fossil fuels, their importance, and their problems.

the course is organized into three parts: 1) how fossil fuels form (in an intro to earth science perspective), 2) what fossil fuels are and energy systems, 3) the effects of fossils fuels and climate change.
The economics, history, science, and statistics behind fossil fuels.
Fossil fuel systems, basic geology, and basic information regarding energy policy
Overall knowledge on Fossil Fuel industry and how energy is produced in a general sense

A great introduction to the world of Fossil Fuels Energy, especially for those with no background in energy. Throughout the course, I was able to understand the impact of fossil fuels on our economy, its origins, and its various uses.
General knowledge about fossil fuels, world energy sources, and earth / environmental science.
How to navigate relevant information sites and analyze current fossil fuel basins around the world
Overview of fossil fuels and its implications
I learned about lots of fossil fuels and world energy.
I learned a lot about the world of oil!
Basic knowledge about energy sector
I learned about world energy use, how fossil fuels are formed and used, and their effects on environments and climate.
technical underpinnings of fossil fuels, extraction etc.
I learned a lot about the fossil fuel industry from how it developed and where it goes from here.
SO many things i would never expect!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved how accessible this class was, the zoom option and the free 48-hour grace period for problem sets were liesavers.

Strengths: This course was flexible and Prof O. emphasized learning and grasping concepts more so than the technicalities. Weakness: There is a lot of content that sometimes you don't know what will be tested.
Strength is that the exams are open note and the course content is interesting. Weakness is that there is a lot of material covered in each lecture and it can sometimes be overwhelming.

The course is very intricate and extensive. I enjoyed the fun facts Professor O included throughout the lectures, it kept me interested and happy. At times, I do wish the problem sets related a little more to teaching material.

Strengths: Homework load is low. Most of it is just performing unit conversions and reading graphs. 

Weaknesses: Lectures are quite boring, and do not adequately prepare us for the midterm or final exams. Every point in this class corresponds to one percent of your grade, so missing even a few questions can have a substantial impact.
Strengths: straightforward grading and the professor was incredibly attentive/supportive. Weaknesses: none
Strengths: very informational and Prof. Oristaglio is an expert in the field. The PSets helped to reinforce things we learned in class and allowed us to explore relevant topics and add our own ideas.
I thought the content was really easy to follow along, but found the lectures a little boring and the slides pretty repetitive.
More interactive
More engaging lectures
It's a good class for non-science majors to be introduced to the discipline, however I did not find the material very engaging.
Strengths included challenging, thought-provoking homework assignments and interesting course material. Weaknesses included tedious lectures and unhelpful teaching fellows.

Strengths: The professor is passionate and excited to teach about fossil fuels and energy. He had the coolest pumpkin on Halloween! It is cool, relvamt content to a lot of things in the world right now.
Weaknesses:  Weakness was that because the class was a little large for the room, the class got moved half on zoom. You could go in person, but once the zoom option was there for half the classes,  had trouble not using. It generally made me less engaged and I had trouble staying focused during zoom class. I wish the Psets were more regularly spaced throughout the semester instead of stacking up on the end.

The biggest strength of this course is professor oristaglio. He is EXTREMELY knowledgeable about fossil fuels and has decades of experience in the industry. The biggest weakness is that it can sometimes feel disorganized. The course covers a wide range of topics and you may go from learning about economics to geology to chemistry in the same week.

Strengths: knowledgable and kind instructor, interesting content. 
Weaknesses: low in-person attendance (there's a live Zoom option), so lectures can seem empty and boring.

Strengths- gives u two weeks to do pset with 48 hr grace period. All lectures are recorded. All exams are open note and you can email which day you want to take them

Weakness- Psets are a little lengthy
The content is super relevant and very very engaging. One of my favorite classes at Yale.
The material from the P-Sets and Exams can be disconnected at times.
Strengths are that Professor Oristaglio is a very engaging lecturer and clearly cares about the course. Weaknesses: The grading was at times unclear

Strengths: a lot of content that isn't too hard
Weaknesses: it's not so well organized

You can tell Michael is incredibly knowledgeable about the topic, and his ability to answer questions is phenomenal. However, while teaching, he spent (I believe) too much time on statistics and data about fossil fuels and not enough time explaining the history or scientific concepts. I found the presentation of data (like percents of different fossil fuels use) to be repetitive and take too much time.
Really interesting and important content but the plate tectonic stuff is tough and on the dry side
Wish the psets were more engaging and involved more background research
The problem sets are well designed to emphasize the learning from lectures.
The lectures are a strength. Professor Oristaglio is clearly very knowledgable and makes the lectures interesting but simple enough to follow along.

Really great material and coverage of fossil fuels. Professor was clear with what to expect and conveyed messages clearly.

The final exam was very difficult in terms of the expectation of a deeper understanding rather than a general overview of the material. It would be great if the class has more group discussion and reflection.
I think having every class in person would've been better.
Although the professor was extremely interesting, he was not always the most engaging.

Strengths: Good, clear PowerPoints; few PSETs and assignments; in-person/online format so easy to adjust if you don't want to walk to the other end of the Earth
Weaknesses: Can be kind of boring if you're not super into the subject; in-person/online format made it easy for me to disengage ; exams were lowkey a scramble to find information and were kind of confusing to me. In addition, all the office hours are held at basically the same hour every single day, which means if you have one obligation at the same time every day, you can't make any of them (not conducive to a student-athlete's schedule). I also would have appreciated if some office hours were closer to main campus.

The course was really fair in its exams and in its PSETs! I think the professor could go more in depth on each topic, because it kinda felt like we stayed at a surface level the whole time, but to be fair there was a lot of content, and that could have hurt student performance.
could do with more lenient grading on p sets

Strengths: Interesting material, comprehensive in scope

Weaknesses: None.
He is lovely and well informed. Lots of information. Sometimes there are so many details its hard to absorb the overarching picture.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It's a science gut for athletes who don't want to spend any time or engagement on it. Otherwise, a good skip. The course goes very slow and often stunted.
yes

Yes I would. I came in knowing nothing about fossil fuels and the whole oil industry and now I know so much! I am definitely more informed about the world and about fossil fuels and renewable energy as well as the politics and discourse surrounding it. If you are not interested in Earth science this class will be boring, but is informative.
Yes, if you need a science credit. I feel that this was a much more interesting course than some of the other science credits, even if I had to work harder.
I would. The class is very interesting and it pertains to an increasingly important issue of today. Professor O does an excellent job at providing insight on all sides of the argument.

I do not recommend this course. Although the workload is low, the midterm and final exams are quite challenging and test us on material that was not explicitly covered in class. The lectures are boring (the professor skims through a slideshow), and do not clearly teach any concepts. Most of the homework is dull and involves performing unit conversions or graph reading. Every point in the class is worth a whole percent of your grade, so making even one mistake can be consequential. If you're looking for an easy science credit, there are probably better options than this one.
Absolutely!!! Whether you need a SC credit or just want/need to take the class, it will be enjoyable. You learn a lot without too much stress or pressure.
Generally, yes. It is interesting, has a very manageable workload, and genuinely teaches a lot about the topic. I think most people would benefit from the understanding they will gain in the class.
This class felt a little too pro-fossil fuels at times, and also went a bit too deep into geology and ancient petroleum system formation, but overall I found the class interesting and useful.
Yes
If for science credit only
Yes! Good course and applicable knowledge

No, I wouldn't. I think there was too much confusing material. We jumped from balancing chemical formulas to thermodynamics to tectonics and it was really hard to follow and tie the lectures together.
Yes! It was very interesting!

I would recommend this course not only to environmental studies or planetary science majors, but also students interested in political science and global affairs. About half of the class is structured around the serious science of fossil fuel creation and application as energy sources, but the other half is seriously policy-oriented and deals a lot with the nature of fossil fuel usage around the world as one of, if not the, top commodity on the global market.

It was a good, take-on-able science for someone who doesn't know science. They introduced all concepts, and t was really good about not assuming knowledge that I didn't have. It was approachable but also delved into real topics. I wish it hadn't been half zoom and if it wasn't would have been easier to engage in.
Yes. It will not take up much of your time and the lectures are interesting. If you want to learn a ton about fossil fuels then you will find this course interesting.

I recommend it as a science credit. It wasn't that difficult and the content is interesting. Workload isn't nothing, and you will have to do the psets and study for the midterm and final, but it's a good class.
Yes, especially if interested in Energy because you learn so much every single class.

Yes. It gives a good overview of fossil fuel systems and the current state of world energy. Note that this course is very earth science heavy; you won't learn much about fossil fuel markets/policy/industry as whole. It's more about the earth science of petroleum and coal fields.
It's good for a science credit.
I would recommend this course to another student. It teaches you about an important and often under appreciated topic which is the world energy system.
Not really... it was fine but i didn't like it all that much and it wasn't an easy A for a science credit like I was hoping.

Yes, I will say it is a bit boring at times. Be prepared to hear a lot of statistics about fossil fuels. However, the material itself is very interesting and the Orestaglio is very knowledgeable if you ask questions. The option to do remote on some days was nice too.
Good science credit on an important topic. Its not a gut to be honest  you have to study diligently for the tough exams, but good class overall.
Yes if they are interested in entering the renewable energy field
Great course for anyone interested in Energy and the professor is extremely knowledgeable.

I would recommend this course if you are actually interested in the fossil fuels / earth science. The course is very well taught and organized, but it can definitely be a bit of a drag if you aren't actually that interested in the material at hand.
Absolutely recommend to anyone studying energy, geology, chemistry, economics, or the environment!
Definitely, interesting material that is a great break from other coursework
Yes, especially for those who do no have any understanding of fossil fuels and energy
Yes
Yes! You get as much out of it as you put in.

Yes, if they want a low-workload class or 5th class. 6 PSETS, one midterm, and one final is a steal at Yale. If you put in the effort to go to office hours for the PSETS (make sure to find a good TA), you can get really good grades on the PSETS. Midterm and final are harder, but they are open-notes and open-internet.
yes

If you want a pretty easy science credit and enjoy learning and talking about the environment, fossil fuels, and climate change, absolutely take this course! It was fun and professor Oristaglio is fantastic.
very interesting

I would recommend taking this course, along with Renewable Energy in the Spring, for any student, regardless of major. Everything in our world today revolves around energy. This course and Renewable Energy provide an excellent introduction to the expansive world of energy and opens up many possible ways to get involved in the industry.
Yes! It is not quite a gut but it is not too hard if you are genuinely interested and engaged.
